headline: The Memo: Trump no longer holds MAGA movement in his palm
author: Niall Stanage
sentences: Trump endorsed Brooks way back in April 2021  just three months after the Alabama congressman had delivered an incendiary speech at the Jan. 6, 2021, Stop the Steal rally that immediately preceded the riot at the Capitol.

But Trump rescinded the endorsement in March, apparently irked by Brookss statement that it was time to move on from the 2020 election  and by Brookss failure, at that point, to gain traction in the polls.

The endorsement is personal to Trump, so when he rescinds an endorsement, what effect does that have on the locals who may identify with Trumps principles but resent the taking back of his endorsement?
An Alabama Daily News-Gray TV poll released late last week showed him just 2 percentage points behind first-placed Katie Britt, a former chief of staff to retiring Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.).
Brooks, in turn, spoke out about Trumps attempts to get him to rescind the 2020 election result, and even by ridiculing Trump for describing the fervently conservative congressman as woke.
Conservative commentator Kathy Barnette likely drew some votes away from Oz because she was seen by some GOP primary voters as a more authentic representative of MAGA-style populism.
To be sure, Trump has also scored big victories this primary season  wins in which the separation between the MAGA movement and the man who inspired it seemed vanishingly small.
Yet, despite all that back and forth, Brooks has continued to position himself as a stalwart supporter of the America First populism that has characterized the MAGA movement.
The complexity of the situation reflects a push and pull between Trumps personal desires and how GOP voters might see their own senator, congressman or governor.
He is also the hot favorite to win the presidential nomination in 2024 if he wants it  as even internal critics like Sen. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) have acknowledged.
The same is true of Trumps former White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, who will likely become the Republican gubernatorial nominee in Arkansas.
The contest in the Keystone State was especially telling because Trumps endorsement of Oz seemed mostly rooted in the candidates successful TV career.
In North Carolina, Trumps support of scandal-prone Rep. Madison Cawthorn (R) was not enough to save the congressman from a primary defeat.
On Monday, he issued a statement that included a link to a news story suggesting Brooks was still touting Trumps endorsement in mailers.
Another Trump favorite, former football star Herschel Walker, is all but certain to win the GOP Senate primary in Georgia on Tuesday.
But Tuesdays primaries will show, once again, that the firmness, or otherwise, of his grip on the GOP is a complicated question.
The Hill has removed its comment section, as there are many other forums for readers to participate in the conversation.
Trump has wrought real and lasting change on the GOP since he began his run for the presidency back in 2015, they say.
The dynamic looks like it will become starker on Tuesday, when primaries are held in Alabama, Arkansas and Georgia.
Trump made his endorsement but there were others there appealing to the same anti-elitist, populist sensibilities.
In some important primaries this year, they have instead bucked his wishes  and theyre set to do it again.
In Pennsylvania and Ohio especially, you had multiple candidates who were very much in that Trump lane.
Vances victory in the Ohio Senate primary, which was almost entirely attributable to Trumps backing.
There is clearly an appetite for that within the party that is not specific to Donald Trump himself.
Kemp has a wide lead in opinion polls over Trumps preferred pick, former Sen. David Perdue (R-Ga.).
Virtually all Republicans agree that Trump remains far and away the dominant figure in the party.
In last weeks Senate primary in Pennsylvania, Trump backed Mehmet Oz, better known as TVs Dr. Oz.
Brad Blakeman, a GOP strategist who served in former President George W. Bushs White House, said.
Oz may yet prevail, but if he does so it will be by a tiny margin  and probably after a recount.
There, Rep. Mo Brooks (R-Ala.) has surprised Trump World by picking up steam in the final weeks.
The Republican gubernatorial primary in Georgia will be the most closely watched race of all.
President Trump and the MAGA movement are showing signs of moving in different directions.
What does Trumps endorsement mean if the people on the ground have a different opinion?
Tuesdays races in Georgia and Alabama are not the first time those forces have swirled.
Its hard to tease out exactly what is going on, said GOP strategist Dan Judy.
In the RealClearPolitics polling average on Monday, Kemp led by 22 points.
But that doesnt mean his word is the law for GOP voters in every race.
In Idaho, a Trump-backed challenger failed to displace incumbent Gov.
Trump is plainly irritated by the way the Alabama race has unfolded.
Republican insiders argue that two facts are too often confused.
The situation is cloudier in the GOP Senate primary in Alabama.
By no stretch of the imagination is Trumps base deserting him.
We invite you to join the discussion on Facebook and Twitter.
But nor are those voters willing to simply do his bidding.
As always, there is a danger in underestimating Trump.
The most notable example so far came with author J.D.
Brian Kemp (R) appear unlikely to pay dividends.
The Memo is a reported column by Niall Stanage.
